title-group.article-title: Influence of S. mutans on Base-metal Dental Casting Alloy Toxicity

article-meta.aff: 1Materials Science Unit, Dublin Dental University Hospital, Trinity College Dublin, Ireland
2Microbiology Unit, Division of Oral Biosciences, Dublin Dental University Hospital, Trinity College Dublin, Ireland

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 International & American Associations for Dental Research
permissions.copyright-holder: International & American Associations for Dental Research

abstract.p: We have highlighted that exposure of base-metal dental casting alloys to the acidogenic bacterium Streptococcus mutans significantly increases cellular toxicity following exposure to immortalized human TR146 oral keratinocytes. With Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS), S. mutans-treated nickel-based (Ni-based) and cobalt-chromium-based (Co-Cr-based) dental casting alloys were shown to leach elevated levels of metal ions compared with untreated dental casting alloys. We targeted several biological parameters: cell morphology, viable cell counts, cell metabolic activity, cell toxicity, and inflammatory cytokine expression. S. mutans-treated dental casting alloys disrupted cell morphology, elicited significantly decreased viable cell counts (p < 0.0001) and cell metabolic activity (p < 0.0001), and significantly increased cell toxicity (p < 0.0001) and inflammatory cytokine expression (p < 0.0001). S. mutans-treated Ni-based dental casting alloys induced elevated levels of cellular toxicity compared with S. mutans-treated Co-Cr-based dental casting alloys. While our findings indicated that the exacerbated release of metal ions from S. mutans-treated base-metal dental casting alloys was the likely result of the pH reduction during S. mutans growth, the exact nature of mechanisms leading to accelerated dissolution of alloy-discs is not yet fully understood. Given the predominance of S. mutans oral carriage and the exacerbated cytotoxicity observed in TR146 cells following exposure to S. mutans-treated base-metal dental casting alloys, the implications for the long-term stability of base-metal dental restorations in the oral cavity are a cause for concern.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Ni-based dental casting alloys are routinely used for prosthodontic and orthodontic appliances in dentistry (Noble et al., 2008), despite an acknowledgment of Ni being the most allergenic of all metallic elements (Spiewak et al., 2007). Studies have identified exacerbated levels of Ni ion leaching from dental restorations (Garhammer et al., 2004; Amini et al., 2012). Ni-based dental casting alloys are exposed orally to dynamic forces, including changes in pH (Wataha et al., 1998) and temperature (Faria et al., 2009), and to mechanical forces (Ahn et al., 2010). Chromium, the foremost alloying element in Ni-based dental casting alloys, augments the alloys’ corrosion resistance potential by generating a protective oxide layer (Wylie et al., 2007), allowing the alloy to interact with surrounding oral tissues without adverse host responses. Unfortunately, the oxide layer can be disrupted by pH shifts, resulting in increased metal ion leaching over time (Brune, 1986).

Dental caries, the most prevalent bacterial disease (Berkowitz, 2003), is primarily caused by colonization of the oral cavity by acidogenic S. mutans (Mayanagi et al., 2011). S. mutans, a lactic-acid-producer, has the capability to reduce intra-oral pH levels during and following the ingestion of foods and liquids (Aamdal-Scheie et al., 1996), resulting in demineralization and subsequent loss of enamel and dentin (Takahashi and Nyvad, 2011). Wataha et al. (1998) determined that transient exposure to reduced pH solutions amplifies metal ion leaching from Ni-based dental casting alloys. Therefore, the leaching of metal ions from base-metal dental casting alloys into the surrounding oral mucosal tissues is expected (McGinley et al., 2012). We postulated that the biocompatibility potential of base-metal dental casting alloys would significantly decrease following exposure to S. mutans, since a decrease in pH during S. mutans growth could disrupt the non-conductive barrier present on the surfaces of base-metal dental casting alloys (Roach et al., 2000). Clinically, dental caries may contribute to the occurrence of patient Ni hypersensitivity from base-metal dental appliances. Consequently, the implications of oral bacterial disease should not be underestimated in restorative dentistry. Our hypothesis-driven study aimed to explore the significance of S. mutans exposure on the biocompatibility of base-metal dental casting alloys.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: All base-metal dental casting alloy disc-shaped specimens (Ivoclar-Vivadent, Schaan, Liechtenstein; Table) were cast (1.0 mm thickness, 10.0 mm diameter) and polished to a clinically relevant surface finishing condition (McGinley et al., 2011a) and sterilized individually in an autoclave at 121ºC for 15 min in Defend® Self-Sealing Sterilization Pouches (Carl Parker Associates, Mydent Corporation, New York, NY, USA). Sigma-Aldrich Ltd. (Dublin, Ireland) supplied all reagents unless otherwise stated.

fn.p: Composition (in mass%) of Ni-based (d.Sign®10 and d.Sign®15) and Co-Cr-based (d.Sign®30) dental casting alloys according to the manufacturer.

ICP-MS analysis of 1-, 7-, and 14-day alloy-disc immersion solutions for the S. mutans-treated dental casting alloys with values in µg/L. *ICP-MS values for the untreated base-metal dental casting alloys are included from previously published data (McGinley et al., 2011b) for comparative purposes.

sec.title: Bacterial Exposure
sec.p: S. mutans 25175 (American Type Culture Collection, Manassas, VA, USA) was cultured for 24 hrs in 10 mL tryptone soy broth (TSB, Oxoid, Hampshire, UK). Sterilized disc-shaped specimens of the base-metal dental casting alloys investigated were incubated with stationary-phase S. mutans at 37°C for 24 hrs. S. mutans-treated alloy-discs were washed in Millipore™ Milli-Q®-Biocel water (Cork, Ireland) and re-sterilized. Alloy-discs not exposed to S. mutans were included as untreated controls. Alloy-discs were incubated in TSB only as an additional control.

sec.title: ICP-MS Analysis
sec.p: S. mutans-treated and untreated alloy-discs were immersed in 50 mL phenol red-free Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM) at room temperature for 1, 7, and 14 days. Resultant immersion-solutions underwent ICP-MS analysis (Agilent 7500a Series® Instrument, Agilent Technologies, Dublin, Ireland) to quantify leached eluents (µg/L). ICP-MS was performed on one occasion with a single sample of each alloy-disc.

sec.title: Alloy Exposure
sec.p: TR146 oral keratinocytes (SkinEthic Laboratories, Nice, France) were maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum and 100 µg/mL penicillin/streptomycin [complete medium (CM)] at 37°C, 95% humidity, and 5% CO2 (normal conditions) until confluent. TR146 cells (2.0 x 103 in 2 mL CM) were grown in 6-well cell culture plates (Cellstar®, Greiner Bio-One Ltd., Gloucester, UK) for 24 hrs, under normal conditions, prior to direct exposure to S. mutans-treated and untreated alloy-discs incubated under normal conditions for a maximum of 72 hrs, for the determination of cell morphology, viable cell counts, and inflammatory cytokine expression. CM was refreshed for all TR146 cells at 2, 24, 48, and 72 hrs. Critically, confluent TR146 cells were exposed to S. mutans-treated and untreated alloy-discs by immersion in 50 mL DME for 1, 5, 9, and 14 days (immersion duration) for cell metabolic activity and cell toxicity analyses. Experiments assessing cellular responses were repeated 3 times, with new alloy-disc specimens and cell cultures each time.

sec.title: Cell Morphology
sec.p: Cell morphology was observed at 48 hrs following exposure of TR146 cells to S. mutans-treated and untreated alloy-discs (Nikon™ Eclipse TS100 inverted-microscope, Micron Optical Co. Ltd., Dublin, Ireland).

sec.title: Viable Cell Counts
sec.p: The trypan blue dye technique (McGinley et al., 2011b) was used in triplicate at 2, 24, 48, and 72 hrs (exposure time) on TR146 cells following exposure to S. mutans-treated and untreated alloy-discs.

sec.title: Cell Metabolic Activity
sec.p: We used an XTT assay (McGinley et al., 2011b) to determine cell metabolic activity following exposure of TR146 cells to S. mutans-treated and untreated alloy-disc immersion solutions (1, 5, 9, and 14 days). Measurements were recorded in triplicate at 2, 24, 48, and 72 hrs (exposure time).

sec.title: Cell Toxicity
sec.p: Intracellular lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels were measured in triplicate with CytoTox96™ (Promega, Dublin, Ireland) at 2, 24, 48, and 72 hrs (exposure time) following exposure to S. mutans-treated and untreated alloy-disc immersion solutions (1, 5, 9, and 14 days). TR146 cells treated with 1% Triton-X100 were used as positive controls.

sec.title: Inflammatory Cytokine Expression
sec.p: Interleukin 1-α, (IL-1α), Interleukin-8 (IL-8), Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2), and Tumor Necrosis Factor-α (TNF-α) enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays were performed (RnD Systems Ltd., Abingdon, UK) in triplicate following exposure of the TR146 cells to S. mutans-treated and untreated alloy-discs for 24 hrs (exposure time).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analyses were performed with SPSS V12.0.1 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA), with a critical significance level of p < 0.05. To check for significant trends of increasing exposure time (2-72 hrs), we conducted linear regression analyses for viable cell counts (n = 6), cell metabolic activity measurements (n = 6), and cell toxicity data (n = 6) following exposure of TR146 cells to S. mutans-treated alloy-discs and for the control cells (n = 3). Further regression analyses examined significant trends of increasing immersion duration (1-14 days) with cell metabolic activity (n = 3) and cell toxicity data (n = 3) for each alloy. One-way analyses of variance (ANOVA) (n = 7), with Tukey’s post hoc tests where required, were conducted on the pooled data for viable cell counts, cell metabolic activity measurements, cell toxicity data, and inflammatory cytokine expression levels. The data presented for the untreated dental casting alloys (for comparative purposes) have been published in McGinley et al. (2011b).

sec.title: ICP-MS Analysis
sec.p: S. mutans-treated Ni-alloy-discs leached increasing levels of Ni ions (104.5-455.8 µg/L compared with 68.4-417.5 µg/L) and Cr ions (25.9-54.1 µg/L compared with 11.5-29.7 µg/L) over the 1- to 14-day immersion duration compared with untreated alloy-discs (Table). The S. mutans-treated Co-Cr-based alloy-discs also significantly increased Co and Cr ion release levels compared with untreated Co-Cr-based alloy-discs (Table).

sec.title: Cell Morphology
sec.p: At 48 hrs, untreated control cells displayed normal cell attachment and morphological appearance (Fig. 1A). Direct-cell exposure to S. mutans-treated alloy-discs at 48 hrs induced cell membrane symmetry and dimension losses (Figs. 1B-1D). S. mutans-treated Ni-based alloy-discs (Figs. 1B, 1C) elicited cell blebbing at 48 hrs; however, S. mutans-treated Co-Cr-based alloy-discs did not (Fig. 1D).

caption.p: Morphological assessments at 48 hrs of (A) untreated control cells and TR146 cells following direct exposure to S. mutans-treated (B) d.Sign®10, (C) d.Sign®15, and (D) d.Sign®30 alloy-discs. Morphological assessments at 48 hrs of untreated (E) d.Sign®10, (F) d.Sign®15, and (G) d.Sign®30 alloy-discs [McGinley et al. (2011b)] have been included for comparative purposes. Scale bars indicated at 5 µm.

sec.title: Viable Cell Counts
sec.p: Changes in viable cell counts with increased exposure time from 2 to 72 hrs are shown in Fig. 2A. Linear regression analyses of untreated control cells highlighted no significant decrease (p = 0.0577) in viable cell counts with increasing incubation time (2-72 hrs). Following direct exposure to S. mutans-treated alloy-discs, significant decreases in viable cell counts were evident (p < 0.0002) as exposure time increased (Fig. 2B). One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and associated Tukey’s post hoc tests indicated significant decreases in viable cell counts for S. mutans-treated alloy-discs compared with untreated alloy-discs (all p < 0.0001; see Appendix Table).

caption.p: Viable TR146 cell counts. (A) Viable cell counts of the untreated control cells and following direct exposure of the TR146 cells to S. mutans-treated and untreated Ni-based (d.Sign®10 and d.Sign®15) and Co-Cr-based (d.Sign®30) alloy-discs at 2, 24, 48, and 72 hrs. [Viable cell counts for the untreated base-metal dental casting alloys are included from a previously published study (McGinley et al., 2011b) for comparative purposes.] (B) Linear regression analyses of viable cell counts for untreated control cells and following direct exposure of TR146 cells to S. mutans-treated base-metal alloy-discs at 2, 24, 48, and 72 hrs.

sec.title: Cell Metabolic Activity
sec.p: Linear regression analysis of untreated control cells highlighted a significant increase in cellular metabolic activity (p < 0.0001) with increased incubation time (2-72 hrs). However, significant decreases in cellular metabolic activity (p < 0.0014) with increased exposure time (1-14 days) were shown following exposure of TR146 cells to S. mutans-treated alloy-discs. One-way ANOVA and Tukey’s post hoc tests showed that TR146 cells significantly decreased cell metabolic activity (all p < 0.0001) following exposure to S. mutans-treated alloy-discs compared with untreated alloy-discs for each dental casting alloy.

sec.title: Cell Toxicity
sec.p: Linear regression analysis for treated control cells showed no significant trend for cell toxicity (p = 0.200) with increasing incubation time, but following exposure to individual S. mutans-treated alloy-discs, significant increases in LDH release profiles were evident (all p < 0.0001). Tukey’s post hoc tests, conducted following one-way ANOVA, identified no significant increases in cell toxicity following exposure to S. mutans-treated Ni-based (p > 0.053) or Co-Cr-based (p = 0.0571) alloy-discs compared with treated control cells. However, cell toxicity levels elicited from TR146 cells following exposure to S. mutans-treated alloy-discs were significantly increased (all p < 0.0001) compared with untreated alloy-discs.

sec.title: Inflammatory Cytokine Expression
sec.p: Low expression levels of IL-1α, IL-8, PGE2, and TNF-α cytokines from untreated control cells at 24 hrs are illustrated by boxplots (Figs. 3A-3D). Tukey’s post hoc tests, following exposure of TR146 cells to S. mutans-treated alloy-discs, showed that significant increases in IL-1α (p < 0.0001), IL-8 (p < 0.0001), PGE2 (p < 0.029), and TNF-α (p < 0.0001) cytokines were evident compared with untreated control cells. S. mutans-treated d.Sign®15 alloy-discs elicited significantly increased IL-1α, IL-8, and TNF-α (p < 0.007) expression compared with S. mutans-treated d.Sign®10 alloy-discs, but not for PGE2 (p = 0.589). S. mutans-treated Ni-based alloy-discs significantly increased IL-1α, IL-8, and PGE2 cytokines (p < 0.0004) compared with S. mutans-treated Co-Cr. Cytokine expression from TR146 cells following exposure to S. mutans-treated alloy-discs was significantly increased (all p < 0.0001) compared with untreated alloy-discs.

caption.p: Boxplot analyses of (A) IL-1α, (B) IL-8, (C) PGE2, and (D) TNF-α inflammatory cytokine expression (in pg/mL) from the untreated control cells and following direct exposure of TR146 cells to S. mutans-treated and untreated base-metal dental casting alloys at 24 hrs. [Values for the untreated base-metal dental casting alloys are included from a previously published study (McGinley et al., 2011b) for comparative purposes.]

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The oral cavity is comprised of fissures, pits, and gingival crevices which allow for biofilm formation by oral bacteria (Cannon et al., 2010), including S. mutans (Tanzer et al., 2012). Since acidic conditions exacerbate base-metal dental casting alloy corrosion (Wataha et al., 2003), we postulated that the pH decrease observed during S. mutans growth (Van Ruyven et al., 2000) would disrupt oxide layer formation in base-metal dental casting alloys (Roach et al., 2000), thereby exacerbating the loss of biocompatibility previously reported (McGinley et al., 2011b).

ICP-MS analysis of 1-, 7-, and 14-day S. mutans-treated alloy-disc immersion solutions showed increased leachate levels (Table) compared with untreated alloy-discs (McGinley et al., 2011b). The pH-lowering capacity of S. mutans (pH 7.8 to 4.1 after 24 hrs) was postulated to be responsible for the exacerbated metal ion release levels observed; however, to date, the precise nature of mechanisms leading to this increase has not been fully understood. Ni was preferentially leached from S. mutans-treated Ni-based alloy-discs with non-compositional copper (288.6-419.9 µg/L), proving cause for concern due to copper’s toxicity potential (Nelson et al., 1999). It is postulated that the presence of copper could be due to metal contamination during the alloy manufacturing processes. S. mutans-treated dental casting alloys leached higher levels of all metal ions compared with untreated dental casting alloys (Table). Therefore, the long-term burden of metal ions leached in vivo is important and could potentially alter the biological responses of oral tissues to base-metal dental casting alloys in service.

S. mutans-treated Ni-based alloy-discs induced exacerbated TR146 morphological alterations (Figs. 1B-1D) compared with untreated Ni-based alloy-discs (Figs. 1E, 1F), where only exposure of d.Sign®15 alloy-discs to TR146 cells induced cell blebbing at 48 hrs (Fig. 1F), suggesting apoptosis (Vermeulen et al., 2005). However, both Ni-based alloy-discs induced apoptotic-like cell death in TR146 cells (Figs. 1B, 1C) following pre-treatment with S. mutans, indicative of the cytotoxic effects of enhanced metal ion release (Table). Increased levels of leachates observed following pre-treatment with S. mutans (Table) exacerbated the morphological alterations of Co-Cr-based alloy-discs on TR146 cells (Fig. 1D), resulting in cell detachment and death not observed for untreated Co-Cr-based alloy-discs (Fig. 1G).

The XTT assay, an enhanced method of quantifying cell metabolic activity compared with conventional metabolic methods (Lu et al., 1997), was used, since metabolic performance is a fundamental indicator of cell function. Release of intracellular cytosolic LDH as an indicator of cellular toxicity is a sensitive method of assessing cell membrane integrity following exposure to cellular stresses (Issa et al., 2004). All S. mutans-treated alloy-discs showed significantly decreased viable cell counts and cell metabolic activity responses (all p < 0.0001) compared with untreated alloy-discs, indicative of major disruption to cellular homeostasis (Brand, 1997). Our contrasting findings (McGinley et al., 2011b) highlight the significance of oral bacteria when base-metal dental casting alloys are being evaluated for prosthodontic/orthodontic dental appliances. It is essential to reproduce as many dynamic environmental conditions intra-orally as possible, to enhance clinical relevance and applicability (Wataha et al., 2003). Therefore, we believe that the introduction of S. mutans significantly improves the replication of the oral conditions routinely encountered by base-metal dental casting alloys. Concentrations of leachates from S. mutans-treated dental casting alloys (Table) were sufficient for lethal permeabilization of TR146 cell membranes, whereby LDH was liberated, triggering irreversible losses of metabolic activity. The causal mode-of-action behind Ni-based dental casting alloys’ ability to elicit cellular and molecular effects is currently unclear (Wylie et al., 2010); however, metal ions interfere with cellular equilibrium such that a state of oxidative stress is induced, ultimately resulting in cell death (Trombetta et al., 2005). The process of steam sterilization reaches a maximum temperature of 121ºC. Since the base-metal dental casting alloys were cast at 1000-1400ºC, the effect of autoclaving on the surface-finishing condition, surface roughness, or surface chemistry is negligible (McGinley et al., 2011a). Inflammatory cytokines were expressed in significantly increased levels following exposure to S. mutans-treated alloy-discs, indicative of a significant immune response and highlighting a clinically relevant manifestation of an immunological response to base-metal dental casting alloys.

It is essential to assess the performance of base-metal dental casting alloys in acidic conditions, due to the low pH levels located in crevices in vivo where saliva is trapped adjacent to base-metal restorations (Wylie et al., 2007), in addition to fluctuating pH levels from the ingestion of foods and liquids (Aamdal-Scheie et al., 1996). Effects of low pH on the corrosive behavior of S. mutans-pre-treatment on base-metal alloy-discs were evident following ICP-MS analysis (Table). S. mutans-treated alloy-discs were considered sensitive to crevice corrosion, due to exposure to low pH environments, resulting in likely losses of oxygen and associated increases in chlorine and hydrogen ions (Wylie et al., 2007), resulting in oxidative stress (Deng et al., 2007). Therefore, crevice corrosion and reduced pH levels would be manifest at pits and fissures in base-metal dental restorations, including areas adjacent to the gingivae and possibly extending subgingivally to prosthodontic appliances and areas where regular cleaning would be problematic for orthodontic appliances. The authors acknowledge the possibility of residual S. mutans/lipopolysaccharides present on the surfaces of the alloy-discs following sterilization; however, this could not account for the elevated metal ion release levels observed. The possibility of exacerbated immune responses induced by metal ions leached from S. mutans-treated alloy-discs is cause for concern in an environment as aggressive as the oral cavity, especially following prosthodontic or orthodontic treatment with base-metal dental casting alloys. Clinically, placement of base-metal dental casting alloy restorations in areas colonized by S. mutans may decrease the biocompatibility of a dental restoration and could markedly affect the lifespan of appliances, especially in Ni-sensitized individuals. As the findings of our hypothesis-driven study suggest, we propose that base-metal dental casting alloys may leach significantly increased levels of potentially harmful metal ions when placed in an environment where S. mutans is present.

fn.p: This work was supported by the Materials Science Unit, Dublin Dental University Hospital, Trinity College Dublin.
The authors declare no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
A supplemental appendix to this article is published electronically only at http://jdr.sagepub.com/supplemental.
